root.titletext:
Welcome to the virtual laboratory of the Center of Experimental Economics at the University of Copenhagen.

To log on please use the username and password provided to you. After successfully
logging on to the experiment, please follow the instructions.

message.text:
Welcome to this experiment!

This experiment is part of a research project undertaken by researchers from the University of Copenhagen and Université Libre de Bruxelles.

By participating in this experiment you can earn money. The amount of money you can earn will depend on your decisions, but might also depend on the decisions of another person.

More precisely, the experiment consists of two different stages and a questionnaire. The amount of money you can earn in Stage 1 will only depend on your decisions. Your earnings in Stage 2 will depend on your decisions, but might also depend on those of another player. At the end of the experiment the computer will randomly choose a stage and pay you according to your earnings in that stage.

The experiment is anonymous: you will neither learn the identity of the person that you are paired with in Stage 2 nor will the person that you are paired with learn your identity.

During this experiment you and the person that you are paired with will be randomly assigned to one of two different roles. We name these roles 'Person A' and 'Person B'. This means that during this experiment you will be either Person A or Person B. If you are Person A, the person that you are paired with is Person B and vice versa.

On the following screens you will receive explanations which describe the nature of the decision situations you will be confronted with (i.e. which decisions can be taken and what their consequences are).

In general, the experiment will proceed as follows: You will receive instructions explaining the first stage. You will then be asked to answer control questions to make sure you understood the decision situation you’ll find yourself in. Subsequently, you will go through Stage 1 of the experiment. The second stage will then follow the same procedure. Finally, you will answer a short questionnaire to finish the experiment. We will then proceed with the payments.

Stage 1: Instructions

Remember the experiment consists of two different stages and a questionnaire. At the top of the screen you will always find information about your progress, indicating in which stage you currently are.

In Stage 1 you can decide how many boxes you want to click away in a box-clicking task.

The task consists of a series of screens with black boxes. When you click on a black box it disappears. After some seconds the whole screen disappears together with the remaining boxes and a new screen with new black boxes comes up. Your performance on the task is measured by the percentage of black boxes you click away. It is between 0% (you do not click away any black box) and 100% (you click away all black boxes that appear on each screen).

Press 'Next' at the bottom of this page in order to get to a trial round where you can familiarize yourself with the clicking task.

After finishing the trial round, you will learn how this task affects your earnings in Stage 1. For now, you only need to know that your expected earnings from the actual task grow with each box you click away. Hence, the more boxes you click away in the actual task, the more you can expect to earn in Stage 1.

Stage 1: Instructions

You have just finished a short trial round and familiarized yourself with the task. Your performance in the trial round (i.e. the percentage of boxes you just clicked away) does not affect your final earnings in any way. However, the actual task, which you will go through in Stage 1 and which consists of more screens, might be relevant for your earnings. Remember, the experiment consists of two stages and one of these stages will randomly be chosen at the end of the experiment and paid out.

What are your earnings in Stage 1?

Your payoff in Stage 1 is performance-based . That is, your earnings in this stage depend on the percentage of boxes you clicked away. At the end of the actual task you will be informed about the percentage of boxes that you clicked away in Stage 1.

You can either earn 150 DKK or 225 DKK in Stage 1. The likelihood with which you earn 225 DKK is given by the percentage of boxes you clicked away. The more boxes you click away and thus, the higher the percentage of boxes you clicked away during the box-clicking task, the more likely it is that you earn 225 DKK in Stage 1 of this experiment.

Examples:

If you click away 30% of the boxes, you will have a 30% chance to earn 225 DKK in Stage 1 and a 70% chance to earn 150 DKK. If you click away 55% of the boxes that appear during the clicking task, you will have a 55% chance to earn 225 DKK and a 45% chance to earn 150 DKK.

On the next page we will ask you control questions to make sure that you understood the explanations so far. Upon answering these questions correctly you can proceed with the box-clicking task of Stage 1.

Please answer by choosing a number between 0 and 100 where 0 means 0%, 2 means 2% etc.

Stage 2: Instructions

You just finished Stage 1 of this experiment. You will now learn which role you are assigned to in Stage 2 and proceed with Stage 2.

Your Role: You are Person B. In this stage, you will be paired with another person, Person A.

The next pages will give you detailed instructions for Stage 2. Please read them carefully and raise your hand if you have any questions.

Stage 2: Instructions

You just finished Stage 1 of this experiment. You will now learn which role you are assigned to in Stage 2 and proceed with Stage 2.

Your Role: You are Person A. In this stage, you will be paired with another person, Person B.

The next pages will give you detailed instructions for Stage 2. Please read them carefully and raise your hand if you have any questions.

Stage 2: Instructions

Remember : You are Person B and you are paired with another person, Person A, in Stage 2.


In Stage 2 you are paired with another person, Person A. You will be confronted with the same box-clicking task as in Stage 1. The difficulty of the task is exactly the same as before.

This stage, however, is different from the first stage. Person A will not work on the task again. Your performance will generate income for Person A and she will pay you for your work on the task from her income. Another difference is that the payoff you will receive from Person A will either be random or performance-based.

The next pages will explain, what 'random' as well as 'performance-based' means and how this affects the earnings of you and the person you are paired with in this stage.

Stage 2: Instructions

Remember : You are Person B and you are paired with another person, Person A, in Stage 2.


A ‘random’ payoff simply means that you have a 50% chance to earn 150 DKK and a 50% chance to earn 225 DKK. The random payoff is like a flip of a coin which decides whether you get 225 DKK or 150 DKK.

A ‘performance-based’ payoff means that your payoff is determined as in Stage 1. That is, the likelihood with which you earn 225 DKK is given by the percentage of boxes you clicked away in Stage 2. The higher the percentage of boxes you clicked away during the box-clicking task, the more likely it is that you earn 225 DKK.

Stage 2: Instructions

Remember : You are Person B and you are paired with another person, Person A, in Stage 2.


Whether you will receive a random payoff or a performance-based payoff depends on Person A (the person you are paired with). More precisely, Person A will be informed about the percentage of boxes you clicked away in Stage 1 and then chooses between two options. The two options a) and b) that Person A can choose between are as follows:
  1. with a 75% chance your earnings in stage 2 will be performance-based and with a 25% chance your earnings will be random.
  2. with a 25% chance your earnings in stage 2 will be performance-based and with a 75% chance your earnings will be random.
In a nutshell, if Person A chooses option a), i.e. the higher likelihood of a performance-based pay, it is more likely that your payoff in Stage 2 will depend on your performance in the clicking task.

You will be informed about Person A’s choice before you decide how many boxes you want to click away in the box-clicking task in Stage 2. However, neither you nor Person A will be informed about whether your payoff will actually be random or performance-based. You will only be informed about the choice of Person A, i.e. the likelihood with which your earnings in Stage 2 will depend on your performance.

Stage 2: Instructions

Remember : You are Person B and you are paired with another person, Person A, in Stage 2.


Following this, you have to make a decision on how much effort to put into the box-clicking task in Stage 2. Importantly, you will make this decision in two steps: First, you can choose your workload. That is, you can choose the number of screens you intend to work on. You can thereby choose any number between 0 and 25 where 25 is the number of screens you also encountered in Stage 1. In the second step, the box-clicking task will start with the number of screens you have chosen and you can decide, as in Stage 1, how many boxes you want to click away.

Note that your performance is measured as the percentage of boxes you clicked away out of all boxes you could have clicked away on all 25 screens. If you decided, for example, to work on 20 screens (which is 80% of the total number of screens), your performance cannot be higher than 80% even if you click on every box that is displayed. You must also know that the time a screen is displayed is not affected by your choice. As a consequence, the difficulty of the task remains the same, since you have as much time per screen as before.

Stage 2: Instructions

Remember : You are Person B and you are paired with another person, Person A, in Stage 2.


What are your and Person A's payoffs in this stage?

Person A’s earnings in Stage 2 have several components. First, Person A’s choice regarding the likelihood with which your payoff is performance-based is connected to a cost that Person A has to pay. Specifically, Person A’s costs are as follows. If Person A decides that the likelihood with which your payoff in Stage 2 is performance-based is 25%, she has to pay 20 DKK. If Person A decides that the likelihood with which your payoff in Stage 2 is performance-based is 75%, she has to pay 25 DKK. In addition to these costs, Person A pays your earnings but also receives the profit generated from your work on the task in Stage 2. Specifically, her earnings are as follows.

Person A's earnings = 350 + 0.75 * Percentage of boxes you clicked away - Your payoff - Person A's costs

Your earnings in Stage 2 are:

Your earnings = you will either receive a random or a performance-based payoff of 225 DKK or 150 DKK.


Examples :
Imagine Person A chooses a likelihood of 25% and your performance on the clicking task is that you clicked away 40% of the boxes. This means,
[1] with a 25% chance: your Stage 2 earnings are 225 DKK with 40% and 150 DKK with 60%.
[2] with a 75% chance: your Stage 2 earnings are 225 DKK with 50% and 150 DKK with 50%.

Assume now that the random process determines that you receive 225 DKK from the work on the task in Stage 2. Given this, Person A's earnings in Stage 2 are:

Person A's earnings = 350 + 0.75 * 40 - 225 - 5 = 135 DKK

On the next page, we will ask you and the Person you are paired with to answer control questions to make sure that the instructions are clear. Upon answering these questions correctly, you can proceed with the second stage of the experiment.

message.text:
Stage 2: Instructions


Remember: You are Person A.


In Stage 2 you are paired with another person, Person B, who will be confronted with the same box-clicking task as in Stage 1. The difficulty of the task is exactly the same as before.

In this stage Person B's (the Person that you are paired with) performance will generate income for you and you will pay his income for the work on the task.

Specifically, Person B will either receive a random payoff unrelated to his work effort or a performance-based payoff.

A random payoff simply means that he has a 50% chance to earn 75 DKK and a 50% chance to earn 125 DKK.

A performance-based payoff means that his payoff is determined as in Stage 1. That is, the likelihood with which he earns 125 DKK is given by the percentage of boxes he clicked away. The higher the percentage of boxes he clicked away during the box-clicking task, the more likely it is that he earns 125 DKK. Because you are paying him/her eventually, the probability with which Person B receives 125 DKK also affects your expected earnings from Stage 2.

Whether he will receive a random payoff or a performance-based payoff is influenced by you. More precisely, you will be informed about the percentage of boxes Person B clicked away in Stage 1 before you have to choose the likelihood with which he receives a performance-based payoff in Stage 2. You can choose a likelihood of either 25% or 75% where 25% means that there is a 25% chance that Person B receives a performance-based payoff and 75% means that there is a 75% chance that he receives a performance-based payoff.

In a nutshell, the higher the likelihood that you choose, the more likely it is that his earnings, and therefore your earnings, in Stage 2 will depend on his performance during the task in Stage 2.

Person B will be informed about your choice before he decides how many boxes he wants to click away in the box-clicking task in Stage 2. However, neither you nor Person B will be informed about whether his payoff will actually be random or performance-based. Person A will only be informed about the likelihood chosen by you, i.e. the likelihood with which his earnings in Stage 2 will depend on his performance.

Following this, Person B has to make a decision on how much effort to put into the box-clicking task in Stage 2. Importantly, he will make this decision in two steps: First, he can choose his workload. That is, Person B can choose the number of screens he intends to work on. He can thereby choose any number between 0 and 25 where 25 is the number of screens you also encountered in Stage 1. In the second step, the box-clicking task will start with the number of screens he has chosen and he can decide, as in Stage 1, how many boxes he wants to click away.

Note that Person B's performance is measured as the percentage of boxes he clicked away out of all boxes he could have clicked away on all 25 screens. If Person B decided, for example, to work on 20 screens (which is 80% of the total number of screens), his performance cannot be higher than 80% even if Person B clicks on every box that is displayed. You must also know that the time a screen is displayed is not affected by his choice. As a consequence, the difficulty of the task remains the same, since he has as much time per screen as before.

Stage 2: Instructions


Remember: You are Person A.



What are your and Person A's payoffs in this stage?

Your earnings in Stage 2 have several components. First, your choice regarding the likelihood with which Person B's payoff is performance-based is connected to a cost that you have to pay. Specifically, your costs are as follows. If you decide that the likelihood with which Person B's payoff in Stage 2 is performance-based is 25%, you have to pay 5 DKK. If you decide that the likelihood with which Person B's payoff in Stage 2 is performance-based is 75%, you have to pay 30 DKK. In addition to these costs, you pay Person B's earnings but also receive the profit generated from Person B's work on the task in Stage 2. Specifically, your earnings are as follows.

Your earnings = 200 + 0.5 * Percentage of boxes you clicked away - Your payoff - Your costs

Person B's earnings in Stage 2 are:
Person B's earnings = you will either receive a random or a performance-based payoff of 125 DKK or 75 DKK.



Examples:
Imagine you choose a likelihood of 25% and Person B's performance on the clicking task is that he clicked away 40% of the boxes. This means,
[1] with a 25% chance: Person B's Stage 2 earnings are 125 DKK with 40% and 75 DKK with 60%.
[2] with a 75% chance: Person B's Stage 2 earnings are 125 DKK with 50% and 75 DKK with 50%.

Assume now that the random process determines that Person B receives 125 DKK from the work on the task in Stage 2. Given this, your earnings in Stage 2 are:

Your earnings = 200 + 0.5 * 40 - 125 - 5 = 90 DKK

On the next page, we will ask you and the Person you are paired with to answer control questions to make sure that the instructions are clear. Upon answering these questions correctly, you can proceed with the second stage of the experiment.

question.text:
Final Questionnaire

Imagine the following situation: you are shopping in an unfamiliar city and realize you lost your way. You ask a stranger for directions. The stranger offers to take you with his car to your destination. The ride takes about 20 minutes and costs the stranger about 200 DKK in total. The stranger does not want money for it. You carry six bottles of wine with you. The cheapest bottle costs 50 DKK, the most expensive one 300 DKK. You decide to give one of the bottles to the stranger as a thank-you gift. Which bottle do you give?
How do you see yourself: If I am treated very unjustly, I will take revenge at the first occasion, even if there is a cost to do so.
How do you see yourself: When someone does me a favor I am willing to return it.
How do you see yourself: I assume that people have only the best intentions.
